9.text:
>> Baroness Jenkin: So here we are in central
lobby, this is the heart of parliament, and

13.text:
we are equidistant between the Commons chamber
and the Lord’s chamber. Usually this space

21.text:
is teeming with people, it’s where any member
of the public can come, but today we’re

26.text:
here to talk about the House of Lords, so
we’re going through to the Peers’ lobby.

36.text:
So here we are in the Peers’ lobby, again,
this is usually teeming with people. There

40.text:
might be members of the public who have come
to watch our proceedings and they walk through

43.text:
here to go up to the gallery where they watch
what’s going on in the chamber, but through

48.text:
those gates is the chamber, where of course,
most of our work is done, whether it’s questions,

53.text:
debates or part of the legislation, that is
where it all happens.

57.text:
>> Male speaker 1: The press reports show
how damaging that can be, but I shall indeed

61.text: take all the noble Lord’s points on board.

63.text:
>> Lord Inglewood: We’re right at the heart
of the House of Lord, the chamber, and it’s

67.text:
in the chamber that we debate government policy,
pass laws and generally scrutinise the activities

75.text:
of the whole of what’s going on in Britain
today. And despite the gold leaf, the carved

81.text:
wood, the heavily embossed leather, it’s
actually very much a working chamber and I’m

87.text:
standing at the despatch box which is where
government ministers lead with government

92.text:
>> Male speaker 2: However, I can report to
the house that a pilot who returned these

96.text:
>> Lord Inglewood: Behind me on my right,
here, is the government side and most of these

100.text:
benches are occupied by the peers who are
the government party, save that right at the

106.text:
far end over my shoulder, is where the Bishops
always sit. I’m now crossing the chamber

112.text:
of the House of Lords onto the opposition
side, and the opposition sit along the benches

116.text:
on my left and it’s not only the main opposition
party, it’s also the cross-benchers who

123.text:
are the independents, and one of the unusual
characteristics of the House of Lords is that

127.text:
there is a large independent presence which
means that no one party has an overall majority.

134.text:
There are three other important parts of the
chamber that I think it’s useful to know

137.text:
about, and the first one is the Woolsack,
which is where the Lord Speaker sits. Over

142.text:
to my right here is the clerk’s table and
the clerks are the administrators, the civil

146.text:
servants who keep us all right. And finally,
over my shoulder, is the royal throne.

151.text:
>> Baroness Jenkin: So here we are in the
grand committee room, but it’s also known

154.text:
as the Moses room and you will see from that
picture of Moses coming down the mountain

161.text:
why it’s known as that. It’s used for
debates and where we discuss some of the detail

167.text:
of the legislation, so it enables the chamber
to be used for one bit of legislation and

171.text:
here for another. And the minister sits here
at the despatch box, the civil servants sit

176.text:
behind him and members of the public can sit
here and watch the proceedings in a very intimate

183.text:
>> Lord Haskel: We’re in one of the division
lobbies, this is where we settle our arguments.

188.text:
There are two division lobbies, one for content,
which means you’re happy with the argument

195.text:
and the other is the not content, where you
disagree, and we’re in the not content.

199.text:
If there is a dispute, it is put to the vote,
when the vote is called, bells ring throughout

207.text:
the Houses of Parliament and you have eight
minutes to walk through this lobby. After

212.text:
eight minutes they see how many people have
walked through, they go into the chamber and

218.text:
they will read out who has won and who has
lost, and that’s the way we settle our arguments.

225.text:
>> Lord Faulkes: This is the Royal Gallery,
and the Gallery is used for ceremonial occasions,

231.text:
which don’t take place that often, but it
is used every day for meetings. For example,

236.text:
here we have a table, six chairs, there are
other tables like this and there may be a

242.text:
meeting which has been set up, involving people
from outside the Houses of Parliament, or

247.text:
it may be simply peers hatching together some
plan. Sometimes it’s very crowded and very

252.text:
busy, there’s a lot going on and other times
it’s very quiet and slightly spooky, particularly

258.text:
late at night. That way is the chamber but
it’s on the upper floor that a lot of the

264.text: work is done, in the committee rooms.

266.text:
>> Baroness Parminter: Well we’re up on
the committee corridor and with the House

272.text:
of Lord’s chamber over there and the river
over there and this place is really quiet

276.text:
now, but normally it’s a buzz with people.
Peers will spend as much time up here on the

281.text:
committee corridor as they do down in the
chamber. We just get that sense of everything

285.text:
is alive here, all the issues that are worrying
people out there in the street, are actually

288.text:
going to be talking about here in this corridor.
Well we’re up in one of the committee rooms,

295.text:
some of the rooms are bigger than this, some
are smaller, but they all pretty much look

299.text:
the same, and this is where we do the important
work of scrutinising government policy and

305.text:
trying to influence future public policy debates.
We’ll have people from all parties and indeed

311.text:
no parties, coming together to really dig
deeply into an issue that we feel strongly

316.text:
needs investigating, be it energy or transport
or how we’re going to feed the world in

321.text:
the future.
So these doors here mark the end of the House

325.text:
of Lords committee corridor, down below us
is the Central Lobby, which is the central

330.text:
point of the Houses of Parliament with the
two chambers flowing off from it, the House

335.text:
of Lords on one side, the House of Commons
over there.
